title: Teaching Philosophy
text:
My hope as an educator is to see students walk away from class eager to challenge the state of current understanding. I would like to see students engage in respectful discourse that continues to create and share knowledge. These teaching objectives rely on two main pillars: Mastery and Humility.
Mastery. This pillar is derived by the concept of Shuhari (守破離) that originates from the Japanese tradition called “The Way of Tea” (Chado - 茶道). A similar tradition can be seen in the traditional making of coffee (Buna - ቡና) in Ethiopia. This concept of mastery emphasizes that the fundamental techniques and knowledge do not change. This is applicable in the realm of engineering because the first principles do not change. While materials, fabrication methods, and technology evolve, the core principles remain the same. Shu - Ha - Ri can be broken into three stages. A stage of learning the fundamentals (Shu), a stage of breaking the tradition (Ha), and finally going beyond (Ri). Teachers serve as a guide during a student’s journey to mastering the principles of engineering, or any other fundamental based discipline. It is of uptmost importance for student to take ownership of their education. These stages of mastery resemble Bloom’s taxonomy if the 6 levels are paired down into 3 groups. Students begin learning with remembering and understanding ideas. Then they move towards applying and analyzing. Finally, they reach a point of evaluating arguements and creating original work. I find the role of mentoring students to be a critical position in shaping generations to be active and competent citizens in the global community. This concept of mastery is presnt in my teaching methods by the emphesis of “See - Do - Teach”. A method introduce to me by Dr. Robert Brown, a senior Lecture of Physics at Duke. Students are asked to first observe and learn the principal concept. Second, practice and apply the principal in different conepts. Third, explain and discuss the concept to their peers. The emphasis of course assignments is less on inducing stress, but encourage growth through proper practice and reflection. Inevietable on the journey to master, consistent practice is important. Instead of using homework assignments as a grading assessment they are a means of providing practice of good form. The optional practice problems provided in homeworks are intended to strengthen their problem solving skills. It will be made clear to students in my class that only honest and professional work will be accepted. The main form of assessment will be in-person tests for my classrooms. In order to assess a student’s ability to recal, apply, and evalue concepts students must prepare themselves for a test. The prepartion involved is an important contributor to their learning and structuring the timeline of preperation. However, it is the teacher who must provide fair and reasonable questions based on reasonable expectations. Additionally, teachers must provide constructive feedback for students. Therefore, a distinction between simple satisfactory and unsatisfactory is inadequate. Less graded assignments allows students to practice good form, and teachers to provide quality feedback. As an instructor of undergraduate or graduate level courses, students will be supported but likewise expected to dedicate the designated amount of time for the course. The instructor must make themselves available and establish a welcoming invitation to assist studets. However, as a university student, the expectation is that they are willing to meet the professor half way and also communicate in a timely fashion.
Humility: A teachear serves as a guide in a student’s academic development journey, but they must also reflect on themselves. I believe that the key to mastery begins and ends with humility. Teachers must recognize the limitations of their knowledge, their bandwidth of time, and bias while teaching. The teacher has the responsibility of leading a safe and assessible learning environment. The students also have the responsibility of contributing and engaging with this environment. However, a higher expectation is sent on instructors because they serve as a role mode. As a teacher, I aim to provide all resources in an assesible manner so that all students can engage with the material. The in-class learning activities seeks to bring this to the classroom setting. These activities provide an opportunity for students to internally refect and externally discuss with their peers their understandings. Teachers must also reflect and discuss their understanding! Instructors must come prepared by being knowledgeable in the material they are presenting and honest by sharing the limitations of their understanding. The notion of “authority achieved in the classroom is recieved by giving up your authority” was brought up Dr. Quinn Warnick, during a course on Contemporary Pedagogy at Virginia Tech. Teachers who embrace this vulnerability will leave behind arrogance and walk into a classroom respecting and connecting with their students, in a professional manner. In turn, they’ll serve as a role of model someone who values mastery over perfection and in there journey of learning grow to love their profession. These I find to be the most influential teachers. Often, I notice teachers who have the virtue of humility have naturally captivating lectures. They are individuals, who like storytellers, provide proper context, questioning, and genuine interest that makes a lecture both empowering and exciting to attend. I will admit, this only works to an extent as not all material is appealing to the student.
During my time as a graduate teaching assistant, the lines between teaching and learning became blurred. I was able to work in an environment that both strengthened and humbled me. This setting reminds me of one line in the philoshophy of ShuHaRi that continues to resonate with me. “Dedcate to protect, break or detach, but never forget its essence”. To master teaching, we must become experts in our fields, continue to challenge our teaching methodologies, and never forget that at the core we are also students.

title: Mock Syllabus - SEM 3000
text:
Course Title: Introduction to Structural Engineering

Course Logisitics
Course Number: SEM 3000
Semester/Term: Fall 2025
Meeting Time: MWF 10:10 - 11:00 AM
Class Location: Classroom Building, Room: 101
Course Textbook: K. Leet, C. Uang, J. Lanning, and A. Gilbert, “Fundamentals of Structural Analysis” , 6th edition, McGraw-Hill, 2020, 780pp.
Instructor: Ezra Melaku
Contact Information:
- Email: emelaku@university.edu
- Phone Number: (500)-555-555
Office Hours: MWF 10:00 am - 11:30 am
Office Location: TBD ; Zoom Link: TBD
Website: www.SEM3000.edu



Course Information
Description: Students will be introduced to structural engineering design philosophies and structural analysis methods. This course applies the topics covered in mechanics of deformable bodies to structural systems. Upon completion, students will be able to design members based on fundamental principles such as the principle of virtual work
Course Pre-Requisites: Mechanics of Deformable Bodies
Learning Outcomes:
1. Determine Loads on a structure based on LRFD and ASD Design Philosophies (Demand vs. Capacity)
2. Idealize a structure and assess stability
3. Establish Load Paths and limit states associated of:
- Trusses
- Beams
- Frames
4. Draw Deflected Shapes
5. Solve determinate and indeterimate structures by computing internal loading diagrams (Axial, shear, and Moment) and deflection
6. Explain principal concepts of equilibrium, superposition, compatibility, constiutive relationships, and virtual work.
7. Efficiently design members by verifying software analysis programs with hand calculations


Course Policies
Classroom Environment:
Honor Code:
The University’s Office of Academic Integrity has established policies and procedures that are einforced in this classroom. Information regarding policies and procedures can be found ath the following website: https://universityacademichonestypolicy.edu/. Student are expected to be familar with academic integrity policies and abide by the honor code.
AI
AI is strictly prohibited in the use of this class. The use of AI is considerd unauthorized assistance and violates the academic honesty policy of the classroom.
Attendace
Students are expected to arrive to class prepared to start prior to the designated lecture time. The lecture will begin at the schedule time. The use of technology is only permissible if it doesn’t impact the learning environment of other students.
Accomodations
If you have documented accomodations due to a disabillty or special cirumstances, please schedule a meeting with the instructor within the first 2 weeks of the course or as soon as it becomes known.
Grading Policy
Grade Scale
- 10 Point Grading Scale.
- A - (100 - 90)
- B - (89 - 80)
- C - (79 - 70)
- D - (69 - 60)
- F - (59 - 0)
Grade Contributions
- Final Exam - Optional
- Midterm 1 (25%)
- Midterm 2  (25%)
- Concept Quizzes (20%)
- In Class - Think/Pair/Shair Activities (15%)
- Homework (15%)
Breakdown - Final Exam -
- Optional if Midterm 1 and Midterm 2 are both passing grades. If taken, it will replace the lowest Midterm score (25%)
- Midterm 1 (25%)
- An inperson 2hr exam testing the first half of material
- Midterm 2  (25%)
- An inperson 2hr exam testing the second half of material
- Concept Quizzes (20%)
- Every Friday students will be given a 10 minute quiz at the start of class, students will answer 3 questions that don’t require calculation, but conceptual unerstanding. Each quiz is worth 2%
- In Class - Think/Pair/Shair Activities (15%)
- Every Monday students will spend 10 minutes working on an activity with a partner. The time to complete the assignment will promptly start at 10:00am - Homework (15%)
- Assigned for each unit. Late work will be accepted a day late with a 25% deduction.

title: Homework 1: Solving Determinate and Indeterminate Structures
text:
Honor Statement
Please write out and sign the university academic honesty statement below: Statement:
Signature: __________________________________
Note: Submissions that are not in accordance with the academic honor policy or professioinal quality submission guidlines will not be graded.


Problem 0:
Summarize the keywords, principles, assumptions, and concepts for the topics covered in this unit. This can serve as a review tool prior to the exam, so it is advisable to create a useful summary.


Problem 1:
Read the questions below and answer them upon completion of the problems 2 and 3?

Does the beam have sufficient capacity?
What limit states controls the design for beam BC? (What do you think will cause failure?)
What is the DCR (Demand to Capaciy Ratio) of beam BC? What would be a more material or geometric properties can be changed to increase capacity?
If you were to re-design the structural, what changes would you make to improve efficiency?
The next unit is 2nd order effects. 2nd order effects considers equilibrium on the deformed shape. Based on what you’ve seen in problem 2, how can we use the principal of virtual work to repeatly solve a structure with the same type of loading, but of different magnitudes?


Figure 1: Idealized Structural Model - Problem 1



Problem 2:
a.) Factor the loads according to LRFD.
b.) You are given an idealized structural model in Figure 1. Determine if it is stable? If it is unstable change the boundary conditions such that it is stable?
c.) Determine if the structure is staticaly determinanate. If it is indeterminate, state the degree of indeterminancy.
d.) Draw the deflected shape of the stable structure.
e.) Compute the internal load diagrams (Axial/Moment/Shear) for the beam. Take the length of BC as 10 ft.
f.) Determine the deflection at the midspan of member BC. Is it within the L/360 serviceability limit state requirements?
g.) Calculate the axial, moment, and shear capacity of beam BC given detail 1b in figure 2. The modolus of elasticity, E, is 29000ksi for all members. The depth, t, is 5 inches. The width, w, is 10 inches.

Figure 2: Idealized Structural Model - Problem 2




Problem 3:
a.) Verify that it is stable and determine the degree of indeterminancy of the structure
b.) Based on the factored loads determined in 2a. Solve the structure using the force method. Hint, use symmetry to simplify the strucutre.
c.) Determine the deflection at the midspan of member BC. Is it within the L/360 serviceability limit state requirements?
d.) Verify your results with Mastan2. Provide the internal loading diagrams for the structure. Provide a copy of the text file associated with your model, at the end of your submission.


Opitional Problems:
Complete problems P5.15, P5.16, P5.19, and P5.20 from the textbook.

title: About Me
text:
Background
 Hi, I’m Ezra Melaku and thank you for joining me on this journey through my teaching experiences and philosophies. Before discussing more about my teaching endeavors, here is some background of who I am and where I’m coming from. Originally, I’m from Charlotte, North Carolina. However, home has been many places. In recent years, I’ve spent a majority of my time in North Carolina, Atlanta, Washington D.C, Virginia, and Ethiopia. I began studying engineering after attending the NC School of Science and Math. The rigor of mastering fundamental principles and the sense of empowerment that came from understanding drew me closer to the discipline of engineering. The humility and integrity of civil engineering inspired me to take a step in the direction of structural engineering. As an undergraduate student at Duke University, the underlying pressure to excel academically felt ever present. I became intrigued by effective learning strategies to better manage stress in the context of both physics and life. While working one-on-one with students as a graduate teaching assistant at Virginia Tech, my focus on effective learning grew into a broader interest in pedagogy. Ever since, I’ve worked towards refining my technical skills and my teaching methodology. My lifelong commitment to learning and teaching is a result of mentors and teachers who both challenged and supported me during the early stages of my academic development. I’m truly grateful for their guidance and service. Outside of the sphere of engineering and education, you’ll commonly find me outdoors running or reading. Please reach out if you would like to start a conversation.

title: Mock Lesson Plan
text:
Understand the principles of Superposition, Compatibility, Equilibrium, and Constitutive Law.

Understand underlying assumptions (Linear Elasticity),
Apply the principle of virtual work

Solve indeterminate structures using the force method, a special case of the principle of virtual work

Assemble Flexibility matrices to solve structures with linear algebra





10 min — Think Pair Share Activity

40 min — Lecture

Field any questions from prior class or homework
Recapitulate topics covered in last class
Introduce and cover new material (Force Method)
Reflection Tying back to the Think pair share activity.
Brief overview of topics to be covered in next lecture





Think Pair Share Activity - WEEK 6
- Think Pair Share Activity will be conducted at the start of class and be submitted as students walk out of class. This assignments will be graded based on completion (Note that submissions not abiding to the professional submissions guidelines will not be graded). Students will have 5 minutes to solve it on their own and an additional 5 minutes to discuss it with someone else. Here is an example of what it might entail:
Figure A: Idealized Structure

Context: You are an engineering intern working at a firm. You are told that you have to check the deflection limit for 3 different beams of the same configuration. You only have 5 minutes to complete the task.
Problem: For the given simply supported beam with a ditributed load,w, in Figure A.
- A. Draw the deflected shape
- B. For case 0: w = 1k/ft, case 1: w = 2k/ft, case 2 = 4k/ft, case 3 = 5.5k/ft, Find the deflection given that for case 0, the maximum deflection is 0.1in.
- C. What is the degree of indeterminancy of the structure?
Post-Activity Reflection: Figure B: Idealized Structure with Deflected Shape 
- Superposition allows us to determine the displacement by multiplying the unit displacment by the value of the multiplied load. This allows us to use the unit load method to determine deflection
- Compatability establishes the equation required to solve for the redundant force of an indeteminate structure.
Lecture will be presented by writing on a tablet and projecting my screen with the class.

title: Ezra Melaku
text:
Education:
- MSc, Structural Engineering and Materials, Virginia Tech 2025
- BSc, Structural Engineering and Materials, Duke 2024
Teaching Experience:
Virginia Tech - Graduate Teaching Assistant (August 2024 - 2025)
Listed below are relevant courses alongwith course topics as stated in the syllabus of the instructor of record:

Intermediate Concrete Structures

Class Setting: Graduate Course, Inperson (Class size: 24)

Responsibilities: Office Hours and Grading

Course Topics:

Behavior and design of reinforced concrete structures subjected to both gravity and lateral loads.

Apply methods for predicting structural response.
Concrete Confinement

Moment Curvature relationships in reinforced concrete beams.
Collapse Mechanisms and Force redeistribution.



Intermediate Structural Analysis

Class Setting: Undergraduate Course, Inperson (Class Size: 30)
Responsibilities: Office Hours and Grading
Course Topics:

Stability considerations for supports and connections of structural systems. Solution of statically
Indeterminate beams and frames using the force (flexibility) method and the displacement (stiffness) method.
Use of virtual work to calculate deformations of statically indeterminate structures.
Effect of temperature changes, fabrication errors and support settlements on reactions/internal loadings/deformations.
Influence lines for moving load analysis.
Qualitative sketches for deformed shape and internal loading diagrams.
Approximate analysis of rectilinear frames. Computer analysis of simple structural systems using SAP2000 (Or other software).


Intro to Structural Engineering

Class Setting: Undergraduate Course, Inperson (Class size: 50)
Responsibilities: Office Hours and Grading - For 2 semesters
Course Topics:

Introduction to types of structures, loads, and design philosophy.

Idealization of member connections and support conditions, principle of superposition, determinancy and stability.

Statically determinate structures – solution, determination of support reactions, and internal force diagrams.

Principle of virtual work, calculation of deflections of statically


Design of Steel Structure 1

Class Setting: Undergraduate Capstone Course, Inperson (Class size: 25)
Responsibilities: Co-TA - Office Hours and Grading
Courses Topics:

Importance of strength, stiffness and ductility of steel structural members and their connections.
Structural design, design loads, gravity and lateral load paths, structural stability and the applicability and limitations of building codes.
Principles of structural steel design to simple tension, compression, flexural, and beam-column members as well as simple bolted and welded connections.


Forensic Structural Engineering

Class Setting: Undergraduate/Graduate Course, Inperson (Class size: 30)
Responsibilities: Office Hours and Grading
Course Description:
Forensic Case studies and a broad conception of failure
Formal approaches to investigation,
Role of building codes, ethical standards, government, and legal issues as related to forensic engineering.
Principles of non-destructive testing and structural health monitoring will be discussed.

Bridges, Builders, and Society

Class Setting: Undergraduate, Inperson (Class size: 15)
Responsibilities: Office Hours and Grading
Course Description:

Historical development of bridge systems
Leading bridge engineers and their contributions to the state-of-the-art and state-the practice of bridge design and construction
Basic engineering principles behind bridge design,recognize the social impacts
Development of bridge specifications.
